body.p: Thanks for Prof. Clifford Jones's advice and suggestion and my responses are as follows.

Firstly, actually it is an assumption of thermal emissivity of the tyre surface. Based on the relevant literature, like Zhao et al.,1 the thermal emissivity which is same towards all wavelengths of interest set 0.94 in this experiment.

Secondly, the measured temperature of 27.46 ℃ should be 300.46 K, which induce that the difference is more than 7%. Another point I want to mention is that the increase of temperature from 27.46 ℃ to 32.61 ℃ is the steady mean values of tyre under various vehicle speeds instead of measured ones. Figure 8 shows that in different vehicle speeds, the gap between the lowest steady temperature and the highest is from 12 ℃ to 15 ℃ in the whole tyre surface. Take speed 50 km/h as an example, the lowest steady temperature is 23 ℃ (296 K), while the highest is 35 ℃ (308 K). So the radiative flux referred to the tire area is, at the low end of the temperature range:
0.94*5.7*10−8*(296)4 Wm−2 = 411.3 Wm−2 And at the high end of the temperature range:
0.94*5.7*10−8*(308)4 Wm−2 = 482.2 Wm−2 The difference is more than 17%.

Thirdly, the paper does not point out the precision of ± 0.1 ℃. The instrument used for the experiment is manufactured by FLIR Corporation and its label is TheramCAM E320. Its thermal sensitivity is 0.1 ℃ when the measured temperature is about 30 ℃, and precision is 2%.

ref.citation: ZhaoZLiYWangQ. Application of infrared thermometer in testing of temperature field for a rolling tire. In: Vehicle electronics conference, Proceedings of the IEEE international, Changchun: China, 1999, pp. 98–101.
